dict.string:
Hover your cursor over the buttons above to see what they do. If they have a keyboard shortcut, it'll show that too.
For regular variables, you can change the variable's value using the "Edit" button above on the left. Make your change, then click the green checkmark button to apply the change, or the red X button (or press the Escape key) to cancel it.
(FYI: The variables don't have to be "Local" variables - I just used them in this example so I didn't need to clean them up afterwards.)
For Dictionaries, click the "Help" button to learn how to edit them.
All changes are saved to Keyboard Maestro as soon as you apply them, including the unlimited Undo and Redo.
The OK and Cancel buttons on the bottom right don’t affect whether your changes are saved or not. They just determine if your macro continues, or is canceled.
You can resize this window if you want.
There's a splitter you can use to change the sizes of the panels. The cursor may or may not change to a "resize" cursor, because there appears to be a bug somewhere that messes with the cursor. I don't think it's my bug, but you never know.
{ "test": "Try clicking the JSON button, and the Word Wrap button if you don't want to wrap long lines", "value": "Some value" }
If this isn't showing in a grid, make sure to turn off JSON view mode.
Double-click to edit. Enter to save, or Esc to cancel.
Click the Help button (the "question mark") for more information.
Show the Prompt, either Async or Non-Async
Custom Floating HTML Prompt “Variable Inspector Window”
CANCEL this macro if the OK button wasn't clicked
Custom Floating HTML Prompt “Variable Inspector Window”
